segments.text: Well, the point about the Richter was that he had memorized the classical repertory, which is all the Haydn, Beethoven, Mozart, Scherbert sonatas, piano works, and then he dies, and I imagine his brain goes off much like a television set.
So all those memories are gone.
That great library in Richter's head is gone.
when I read the Milton thing, because that scared me.
That really scared me.
Where did that go?
It's gone.
But the Milton thing of what books are, which is what, if Richter could have written it down, we would have known.
But he didn't have to write it down because he was a pianist.
So we can listen to him play it and imagine anything we like.
But I am now past
two years have been entirely absorbed, and I'm even obsessed with reading Shakespeare and Keats, for very personal reasons.
And now, in fact, I have a list that I want to show you.
Maybe you can help me track certain things.
Keats now is critical to me.
Keats?
Keats is critical to me.
And it's partly from my having gotten over an inhibition of reading great poetry, because, you know,
My lack of a college education always made me presume that if you didn't go to college, don't try to read The Great Masters, because that would be beyond you.
But I'm getting over that.
And so even reading Shakespeare seriously is having gotten over that inhibition.
And certainly Keats and Wordsworth, but the point of it is that in reading them, the purpose always is to find...
what you're looking for in yourself in them.
That's how I'd always done it.

If I was illustrating a book, then I'd look at William Blake, and I'd look at Goya, whoever, always with the joy of looking at work, but always with the not-quite-unconscious motivation that I will find me here, and I will take it, and I will use it for my own purposes.
But what at this point has brought you to Shakespeare and Keats?
It's very interesting to me.
Shakespeare didn't have a university education either.
I know.

And in fact, it was so amusing because once I began to read about everything about him, that amused me a good deal that the critics of the time and other playwrights of the time were very snotty and contemptuous of his lack of good Latin because he didn't go to a proper Latin school.
Yeah, exactly.
And so that was lovely to find the man I'm afraid of was as uneducated as I am probably.
But that's funny inhibition about...
Because I refused to go to college, and it hurt my father very much because of the three children, me being the youngest, I was the only one he could afford to.
He couldn't send my sister, he couldn't send my older brother, and I was the one who didn't want it.
So it was a slap in his face.
My sister would have given anything, but in those days it was worthless sending girls to college.
They were going to get married.
I mean, what else do girls do?
So she, who was probably intellectually the most brilliant of the three of us, was totally...
But you had such a passion for books and for reading.
Why didn't you want a formal education?
I just wanted to work.
And, well, more to the point was an almost congenital hatred of school.
I hated school.
I hated the confinement of school.
And don't forget, we're talking about the 30s now.
Now there's a certain concern for children who don't quite fit in or conform.
There's such a thing as reading disabilities.
We know all kinds of subtleties about handling children.
Not then.
You were just herded into a room.
You were thrown into competition.
The smart one sat in the front of the class.
The dumb one sat in the back of the class, where I mostly sat, because I was numb with anxiety at the endless competition.
So there was no pleasure at all.
It was no fun at all.
And to me, I didn't want to go to art school.
I was still schooled.
I went to the Art Students League simply to quiet my father.
But then you are really the product of your reading, of your observation of other artists.
And ripping off everybody who kept coming.
Shamelessly, right?
Shamelessly.
And one of the things you like, and we will get a Jim Marshall question in now, one of the things you say you admired most, like your good friend Jim Marshall's work, is that he borrowed.
He stole as ferociously as I did.
And we were both excellent thieves, which is one of the reasons we were excellent friends, because thievery in that department is utterly necessary to the creative act.
The whole point is that when you steal something, you cook it, and it becomes you.
If you can't cook it and make it become you, then you're just a cheap crook.
And there are lots of those around, too, as we know.
Some people borrow styles, and it's revolting.
But we prided ourselves on our adroitness,
We were really top-notch thieves, because we could take something, and there was enough of ourselves going, boiling with excitement.
It is like putting it into a night kitchen.
That's where that comes from, a night kitchen cooking pot, and serving it up, voila, a whole new dish.
It's Jim Marshall, or it's me, or any one of the few really terrific people who did books for kids.
Jim was probably best at that,
because he added to it an incredible intellect, an incredible cultivated sensibility, which made his turning it into himself something marvelous.
Because what I envied him about, a number of things, but was the simplicity of it.
Just making sure.
I mean, it's fine.
This is a very warm tribute, and of course this is the 20th.
Let's get rid of the martial arts if you can.
as I did promise Sandy Gore I might do this.
No, and I wanted to.
It's very important.
And this is for my column, which would be a nice 900-word column.
I've got two papers in Connecticut, by the way, and I'll certainly make sure you get tear sheets.
But this is a very warm tribute.
It's the 25th anniversary, I guess, of George and Martha.
And, of course, when you look at these pictures, they seem very simple, don't they?
Yeah.
Just very spare.
Yeah, but that's a great...
adroit beauty of it, that he was not an egotist, he was not a show-off.
Aesthetically, he was so principled.
And the amazing thing is that he started that way.
He wasn't like an artist groping and coming to style.
Jim just came out in full bloom.
When you think how early George and Martha is and how they were already hip, yes, there were refinements.
The Brother Goosebook that came years later is ultra wonderfully refined, but it's all there.
It's one of those rare things, because he was so smart, so verbal, so quick, loved the arts, music, opera, books.
I mean, our conversations on the phone had all to do with music we're listening to, what we were reading, what performances of what we were going to go see.
I mean, he frankly was the only colleague I had in the entire profession where we shared such complicated and lovely interests.
You do say that you believe he's the last.
Yes, I do.
And this is... Oh, that's not hyperbole.
It's not hyperbole.
No, that is not hyperbole.
That article I wrote, it was hard writing.
I rewrote it a dozen times just to make sure there was no hyperbole.
What is happening in the industry now, you know.
We all know.
It is the death of publishing as we knew it.
Let's face it.
It is kaput.
Really?
Yeah.
Yeah.

Certainly as I knew it, certainly a young person coming in as I did in the 50s, I doubt why things would be published now, since most publishers are desperate to keep a bottom line just to sell books, just to stay alive.
You think they're going to experiment with anything off the wall?
It's not possible.
Jim, now I was a lucky kid, lucky dumb kid.
I came into the early 50s, just children's book industry started in the 40s in America.
Bill Scott, who just died last week, broke my heart to read that, began it all with William R. Scott books and Margaret Weisbrown and Bruce Krauss.
I came in maybe five, seven years after the industry began, which was just coincided with roughly the end of World War II.
The industry as we know it.
I mean, there have been children's books.
The industry, yes, of course.
I'm talking about the picture book industry,
The business of picture books as a publishing industry where you can make money viable.
There was always, of course, but there were scatterings.
There was no, I think Bill pulled it together, whether he was conscious of doing that or not.
But he started a new industry, which was the picture book industry, as we know it.
And when I came in, it was just gusting into life.
And everybody was there.
And I was this dumb kid from Brooklyn.
And I had Ruth Krauss, and I had Ursula Nordstrom, I had Crockett Johnson, I had Dr. Seuss, I had, oh, you give up, I had, they're all there, older people, took me on.

They all took me home with them, they all stuck, I had Leonard Weisgard, who, thanks to him, literally took me home, and showed me how to do color separations, and told me how to read, and told me how to look at pictures.
I was an apprentice.
This is an apprenticeship.
I was an apprenticeship for 10 years.
I was apprentice to Ursula Nordstrom at Harper's.
I did any book she told me.
I had no taste.
I had no definition of what I was doing.
She said, Maurice, do this.
And then I want you to do that.
And I said, I can't draw that.
And she said, do it.
You don't want to just draw that.
You want to draw this, too.
I was trained.
So by the time the 50s were over,
beginning of the 60s, starting roughly with the Nutshell Library, I was blooming into an artist.
Late bloomer.
Unlike Jim, who was an early bloomer, I was a late bloomer.
Fortunately for me, I lived long enough so that I bloomed at all.
But that whole period of 60s, fabulous, the world was insane, but publishing was heaven.

And if you do all the crazy books you want, all the great Ruth Krauss books, the books I was allowed to do, which were considered peculiar, were denounced and banned and all that nonsense, still you could do it.
And that lasted right through to the end of the 60s, and we got to peter out towards the 70s when children's books began to make too much money, and we drew the attention of the wrong people.
We drew the attention of the suits.
Because mostly women ran these large departments.
And why?
Because the men wouldn't be caught dead.
And the kiddie book department was like the nursery in the third floor.
You never ran into the grown-up people publishing parties.
And that was a mistake.
We were having such a good time that we were being profitable.
And by being profitable, the men began to sniff.
Not the
the books that began to slip, the money that was coming in.
I'm laying on the table once I really can't stop.
Okay, could you just handle lunch?
Just bring it out?
Thank you.
That was the end.
No, it was the beginning of the end.
Beginning of the end was when Ursula was retired, as far as I'm concerned, mostly unwillingly.
And she became a pain.
her perfectionism, her fanaticism, Nordstrom.
And then things began to change very, very rapidly, and it became a much more, I'm giving you a very rough, gross, generalized overview of the whole thing.
But then becoming an apprentice in the 70s and 80s was getting harder and harder.
You had to come in, and you had to load the cannon and shoot your first book out and be a success in order to get a second book.
It's even worse now.
It's even worse now.
So you've got to score in the first time.
We are on a level of Hollywood now, where you read the thing, the movie comes out on the weekend, and it doesn't make big bucks.
And even the New York Times tells you how much money Men in Black made.
The New York Times is doing that.
That's amazing.
Right.
It's exactly the same in publishing.
If you don't make it on the first few days out, I'm exaggerating, only slightly.
It's true, though.
You're done.
You're screwed.
They're not going to publish you again.
A book's life now can be 30 days, 45 days, and if it's not selling with this return policy, it's back.
They don't even want to return.
They've got a pulpit.
They've got a pulpit.

We used to have books that were on the list forever, and if you didn't sell, well, it'll... Look, if this had happened to me, Night Kitchen didn't sell for years afterwards because of the scandal that arose.
Anyway, please take free software.
Thank you.
Maybe you should bring in another.
No, it's not yet.
Thank you very much.
How do you respond to a, and I'm not going to put you into a, you know, crossfire fire, but I did an interview with Anita Sylvie, an incredibly capable woman.
Yeah, she's a very capable woman.
It's her, and she's of course at Hope Mifflin now.
It's her belief that we're in a, and I didn't even think we'd be getting into this, but it's very interesting.
It's her belief that we're in a new golden age of children's books.
How do you respond to that?
She's talking, of course, technology that makes wonderful stuff available.
The artists who she says are now being attracted to the field.
I will preface what I'm about to say with I'm a 69-year-old man who lives in the country and is absorbed in my own work, in my own reading.
So I say that only to clarify that I don't know what's going on in the real world, okay?
I admit that.
I don't watch TV.
I don't dare.
But I don't agree with her.
I respect Anita tremendously.
We work together on Jim's book.
I don't see a new world at all.
The golden age, you say.
Look, I'm getting older all the time.
I'm in my golden years.
If these are the golden years, give me a raise and I'll slit my wrists.
I mean, getting old ain't perfection at all.
I don't know what she sees that I don't see.
All I see is a beautiful industry crashing.
Crashing.
How...
Do kids grow?
How do they have the time that I have to be apprenticed and work out and become fully developed artists?
There isn't that time.
I defy her to contradict me and tell me where that time is.
I think probably what she said in the next breath was, well, of course, children's books now account for perhaps 20%.
That goes back to what you were saying earlier of the sales.
Okay.
The sales ain't there.
If the sales ain't there, the books ain't there.
But maybe that's what she means by, you know, the... Well, also, maybe also between me and you, and you'll eradicate this on your tape, she doesn't have the freedom to say what I'm saying.
That's right.
She's a publisher.
That's right.
What is she going to do?
I mean, is she going to really admit that she's in a nosedive?
Do you want some of this now?
I'll wait on that.
I'll have a roll, please.
Yes, sir.
And please take one for yourself.
I shall.
Coming your way.
This is lovely.
Thank you.
Yes, it is.
Thanks very much.
But that's what I mean by Jim is the last.
Because he got caught in a squeeze play.
In the sense that he began a little later than I did, obviously.
He suffered, as you read in the article I wrote.
He was ignored by the establishment in terms of awards completely.
just as Dr. Seuss was, because the books were funny and they weren't portentous.
They didn't teach children anything.
They weren't politically correct.
They weren't all those things that give prizes.
I'll always wonder why the Wild Things won the Coltican.
I'm sure there was a rumor I was on my deathbed and I thought they should do it already before the guy croaked, because otherwise I can't figure that out.
Do whatever you will.
But then what happened to him was his unhappiness and disappointment of being ignored, the fact that he never got to sell terrifically well.
What he didn't see, and what I didn't see, was that he was in the get-a-dem-a-rung of all of this, the collapsing of a system that had worked for 20, 30 years.
It was now being shrunk and truncated.
It wasn't time for a Jim Marshall.
He was becoming a kind of eccentric in his own time.
By the time he died, he was popular, but nowhere as popular as he should have been, nowhere as famous and beloved as he should have been.
And could he be alive?
I would explain it to him now.
and that he would torture himself as to what was wrong and what wasn't he doing.
It wasn't him.
The industry was changing right in front of his eyes, but it was so close to us, we couldn't see it.
But knowing what you know, would you advise him to do anything different?
No, no more than I would advise myself, which is continue working.
I'm continuing working, you know.
It's like asking a literary writer to try and write a bestseller.
How are you going to do this?
Well, precisely.
Nothing is going to change.

Me now, the sad thing is I think kids coming in, young people coming in, as I did, have this mindset that they're going to have to do a book that will be very popular, make a lot of money, be able to be merchandised, and hopefully some movie company will be interested to make a film out of it.
Now, that is the way to do a successful book now, as compared to me just having satisfied Ursula Nordstrom.
There was nobody else to satisfy but this woman.
So what do you think is persuading Houghton Mifflin to bring out a 25th anniversary volume of Jim's work?
Well, it's wonderful, because now everybody who hasn't known George and Martha will know George and Martha.
But I mean, what's persuading?
It's certainly not the marketplace, is it?
It's Anita Sylvie, who is a honorable forthright person who loves Jim Marshall's work, and she's a terrific editor and publisher, and she knows this is necessary.
So she's doing it.
She's doing the right thing.
I mean, and also she's publishing something which, God willing, is going to be a tremendous seller.
For people who love George and Martha, they've got an all-in-one volume, and for those who don't know it, they've got an all-in-one volume.
So commercially, it makes sense.
And it helps, of course, that you...
Yes.
Alive yourself with the project.
Okay.
I always feel uneasy about that.
I can understand that.
And I thought modesty makes me uneasy that I should be necessary to help Jim.
I don't even like that.
What I did it for was because I loved him.
And I miss him terribly as a colleague and as a friend.
And there are very, very, very few wonderful artists working in this profession.
And it's a lonely profession.
All art is a lonely profession, all commercial art.
You don't talk to writers.
The only conversations I have is with William Blake, John Keats, Wordsworth, and Shakespeare.
And you know what?
They don't talk back to me.
And these are conversations that you have, of course.
These are passionate conversations that I have.
These are intense conversations.
You asked me the question before which I averted because I didn't want to really talk about it because it sounds like...

putting out too many personal things here but it was the death of my brother two years ago which was catastrophic to me because this was the best person in my life to whose memory by the way you dedicated the Rosenbach yes and Pierre and Pierre because Pierre was his favorite novel I have them both with me these are my two very favorite latest great thank you I brought them with me well he taught me to love Herman Melville he was five years my senior oh yeah oh he was a great the greatest influence in my life
in every way.
And when I illustrated Pierre, the irony of the situation is that he died just before the book was published.
But the reading of Shakespeare came as a result of how to pull myself out of an emotional nosedive.
And I did what everyone has always done, what Melville did when he was... I'm not comparing myself to him except in this one instance that when his depression set in,
of the failure of Moby Dick and the failure of Pierre, he went to Shakespeare.
It's like some people go to the Bible, some people go to Shakespeare.
And Shakespeare was where I went like I scooted there.
No more anxiety about was I smart enough to read Shakespeare.
I knew this was my Bible.
And so it was for the first year after my brother's death and then
just little flickerings and senses and talking to people.
And I have called people whom I don't know who are amazed.
Am I calling scholars for Shakespeare?
I was at Berkeley and I lectured and I met Stephen.
I can help you on this.
Oh, you've got to help me on this.
Helen Bendler.
Oh, Helen.
I'm going to see someone in a couple of weeks.
I give all time.
Okay.
We have so much to talk about.
Shakespeare happens to be my, like don't even,
We'll get into that another time.
We'll have to do that another time.
Shakespeare and Keats, of course.
She's Keats as well.
She has a brand new book coming out from Harvard.
It's huge.
She treats each of the 154 sonnets and major essays on each one.
I called as soon as the proof came in.
I said, you must set up an appointment with
me, for me, with Helen Fennell.
Nick, if I may call you Nick, we have got to work this out.
This is a big project for the rest of my life.
And also, it's making me happy after something that may be very, very sad.
The Keats thing, I don't know what flicked me on to Keats.
Well, he's the best poet who ever lived.
Well, second to Shakespeare.
I think for pure poetry, I have to go with Keats, maybe.
Poetry and Menschkeit.
This is one of the most humane persons I've ever known.
Keats now.
Keats, yeah.
And so I just read, I know what it was.
Somebody said you have to read the Bates biography.
Of Keats?
Yeah.
Yeah, it's excellent.

It's an excellent, it was the first introduction, but not only was it excellent about Keats, it was excellent about the whole English romantic poetry movement, so it got me involved with Wordsworth and Byron and blah, blah, blah.
And mostly it set up the whole situation for me of reading Keats, because he quotes from the letters.
The first thing I did was read the letters.
I read all the letters.
I got the volumes, the letters to George, the soul-making letters.
And I'm thinking, how does this 22-year-old know everything and verbalize something I, in my late 60s, can't?
I feel everything at such a young age.
Yeah, and what is that?
What is that?
What is that kind of rare genius?
You know what?
He's Mozart.
He's Schubert.
Yeah.
These are the very tiny cluster of perfection that has appeared on this earth.
I love this person.
Now I'm reading the poetry, and I'm doing the same thing with Keats that I've done with Shakespeare.
Now I reached a point in Shakespeare where I found what I was looking for, but not consciously.
I just knew I was there, so I had to stop for a while.
And I then went to Keats, and now I'm reading Keats, and I'm waiting like,
Like, what do you call that?
A mine thing?
When you're looking for... That's what I feel like.
What is it called?
I don't know what you're saying.
What is it?
It's not a mine sweeper.
That's a ship.
Well, you know what I mean.
Like a guy who only looks for mines.
That's what I think I look like when I'm reading Keats.
I'm snuffling through everything, and when I find what I want, I'll stop.
Are you... I hate to use the word interacting, but with Shakespeare and Keats...
Verbally?
See, I for one believe that Shakespeare totally thought in images.
I mean, when you look at the imagery, the guy shoots you with an Uzi, I mean, with all different images that come at you.
He had to think in images.
I'll bet you think in imagery.
I do.
Of course I do.
Everything I read, I see pictorially.
That's what I do.
I mean, in terms of actually think in terms of it.
So I'm wondering now what you're getting out of Shakespeare.
Are you getting images?
Is it language coming for us?
It's language engulfed by images, or images engulfed by language.
One sweeping into the other or being eaten, engulfed is as good a word as any.
The plays, I was reading in a very disorderly fashion when I met Stephen Greenblatt at Berkeley, who's the Shakespeare maven, who's a wonderful man, became friends, and he guided me a little bit
and suggested, after my sort of maniacal, enthusiastic chatter, to read such and such plays, and I did.
He recommended Pericles.
So I went straight to Pericles.
It's the best play.
It's what?
I don't think it's his best play.
No, but what is going on in that play?
I choked him.
I'm sorry.
It's like saying Titus Andronicus.
Go ahead.
Well, we know that, you know better than I, that not much of Pericles is Shakespeare.
It wasn't even included in the first folio.

But what has to be Shakespeare is the death of the wife, the so-called death of the daughter, and the resurrection of the wife and the daughter, because he gets into resurrections from Pericles to Cymbeline to Winter's Tale.
which finishes with Tempest.
Okay?
I've been working hard.
When I read Pericles, when he casts his wife on the ocean when she dies in childbirth to his daughter Marina, his wife is cast in the waters and the casket lands on the sand.
Forgive me, Jim Marshall, I'll get right back to you.
She should be dead.
There was a magician living there
And they open it and they spell the roses and essence of flower.
This is Keats.
And they open it and Marina is fresh and alive and beautiful.
Shakespeare doesn't bother to explain.
How come?
He's not a religious man.
This is art.
This is not religion.
And I got so close.
My Geiger counter.
Is that the word?
Well, that's for uranium, but why not?
All right, fuck it.
Whatever it is.
But it's good.
But I like it.
But I like Geiger Conner.
I like it better than the other thing.
I was getting closer.
So then I went to Cymbeline.
That drove me crazy.
Because then we had the same thing.
Somebody thinks somebody's dead.
It's very dark.
It's very dark.
That's beautiful.
The song that the brothers sing over what they think is the corpse of their new little brother, who's really a girl.
I mean, it's Shakespeare.
after Shakespeare, with sexes turned inside out, dead people who are living, living people who are dead.
But what did it was The Winter's Tale.
The Winter's Tale.
That's where I stopped.
I knew my Geiger counter told me, Moishe, here is the gold.
Stop here for now.
Really?
Yeah.
And I did stop there.
I read The Tempest because they...
It was always my favorite, but it was a wrong time for me to read it because The Winter's Tale threw me for such a loop.
The temper seemed pale for the first time, so I put it aside to read it again, but I calmed down.
Then I switched the keys.
Are you searching for something?
Of course, I'm going to write a book.
I'm going to write a book, and it will have to do in some...
essence way about my brother, but it won't be about my brother.
But it'll be profoundly about something I'm scouring for, which I'm always scouring for every time I'm going to do a book, and it takes years to start a book, and I'll be very patient.
If it doesn't get done, who cares?
Can you see it?
Vaguely.
Very vaguely.
Do you see pictures yet?
Yep.
I always see pictures.
I try to ignore them because
Otherwise, I'm seduced by pictures.
So I banish them.
My brain is like a Polaroid.
Never stops making pictures.
And I literally have to tear the film out of the goddamn machine so I can see language and just dwell on language.
What's lovely about Keats, I don't want to draw pictures to Keats.
I did watercolors to Shakespeare.
I couldn't resist.
And they're even being published.
Really?
By Cabin.
When might I ask?
Some have come out, but they're not very happy with it.

be careful with this please I keep forgetting this yeah I will okay otherwise I'll be if you'll feel comfortable we'll go over quotes okay okay you know the point is I the pictures I did are so intensely erotic because when I read Shakespeare I was I couldn't believe how erotic he was how he's like drenched in sex so so am I so when I drew these pictures I did homage to Shakespeare you know
Horny, horny images.
They wanted.
Are they doing it for kids?
No, not for kids.
These are cabin records of old Dick performances on CD.
These are for grown-ups.
So what's the problem?
No problem.
Not my problem.
Not my problem.
Well, look, if everybody made such a fuss in 1970 over Mickey's dick.
No, we're talking about America, right?
Yeah.
which has a problem with such things as dicks.
I mean, a lot of people don't know what a dick is.
I think it's a cancerous growth.
Apparently, a lot of people never saw it in 1970.
I mean, who would have thought I would have opened their eyes to dicks?
A strange, disorderly claim to fame, wouldn't you say?
Right.
So, they're being surprised that I would see Shakespeare in such an erotic light.
Same thing.
Isn't Shakespeare nice with women in long gowns and men in doublets and
You don't expect them to be fucking or anything like that.
That's all I do.
Well, you got some flag for Pierre.
I mean, God.
Are you kidding?
He said, as understatement, I mean, you talk about erotically charged illustrations, but that's what you saw, right?
That's what I saw.
That's what I always loved about the book.
Because it was so hot because Melville is such a black comedian.
We will... Let's go back to Jim.
Well, I have plenty for Jim, by the way.
Believe it or not, we talked about 15 minutes.
Good, all right.
That's a lot of time.
That's a lot of quotes.
And I will write about... But I don't want to sound negative about putting the whole business down and Jim being caught in a trap.
Trust me on this.
All right.
I can say that.
I don't have to quote you on it.
Right.
Because otherwise, if anybody knows I'm a curmudgeon and I sound like curmudgeon,
